characterList.description: Not visually present but narrates the entire video.
characterList.name: Host (Coaster Daddy)

content_metadata.description: This video discusses potential candidates for the Rocky Mountain Construction (RMC) I-Box conversion treatment, focusing on wooden roller coasters in North America. The host provides insights into why each ride could be a good candidate and the potential impact of the conversion.

qAndA.question: Which roller coaster featured in the video has an infamous drop with insane ejector air?
What park added a new coaster every two years in the early 2000s but hasn't received a new one since 2006?

qAndA.answer: It is a dueling coaster with two tracks.
qAndA.question: What unique feature does Le Monstre at La Ronde have that most other potential candidates do not?

qAndA.answer: Retracking and reprofiling the ride with GCI.
qAndA.question: What is one alternative option the host suggests for Arkansas Twister instead of an RMC conversion?

qAndA.answer: Because another Hurler clone (at King's Dominion) was already successfully converted by RMC, and Carowinds could benefit from a similar improvement in its coaster lineup.
qAndA.question: Why does the host believe Hurler at Carowinds is the most likely candidate for an RMC conversion?

activities.description: Host introduces the topic: Potential wooden roller coasters for RMC I-Box conversion

narrativeProgression.description: Introduces the topic and the purpose of the video.

scenes.thematicElements: RMC I-Box conversion, wooden coaster preservation, excitement, and innovation in the theme park industry.
scenes.title: Introduction

videoEditingDetails.description: Montage of various wooden roller coasters
Transition to still image of a wooden coaster

activities.description: Host discusses Cheetah at Wild Adventures

narrativeProgression.description: Discusses the first potential candidate, Cheetah, highlighting its rough ride and unique out-and-back layout.
Host suggests a refurbishment by GCI as a possible alternative

scenes.thematicElements: Ride quality, potential for improvement, nostalgia for older coasters, economic considerations.
scenes.title: Cheetah at Wild Adventures

activities.description: Host discusses Twister II at Elitch Gardens

narrativeProgression.description: Discusses the second potential candidate, Twister II, noting its lack of investment and comparing it to the original Mr. Twister.
Host highlights the ride's potential for a compact, twisted RMC conversion

scenes.thematicElements: Park investment, ride comparisons, potential for standout attractions.
scenes.title: Twister II at Elitch Gardens

videoEditingDetails.description: POV footage of riding Twister II

activities.description: Host discusses Zeus and Cyclops at Mt. Olympus

narrativeProgression.description: Discusses Zeus and Cyclops at Mt. Olympus, highlighting their suitability for a small park RMC conversion.
Host suggests Zeus as a preferred candidate due to its simpler out-and-back layout

scenes.thematicElements: Park size, ride suitability, economic considerations.
scenes.title: Zeus and Cyclops at Mt. Olympus

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of Zeus and Cyclops roller coasters

activities.description: Host discusses Arkansas Twister at Magic Springs

narrativeProgression.description: Discusses Arkansas Twister at Magic Springs, outlining the park's history of adding coasters and suggesting an RMC conversion to boost attendance.
Host offers alternative options like a GCI retrack and reprofile or using GCI hybrid track

scenes.thematicElements: Park history, ride potential, economic factors, coaster technology, alternative solutions.
scenes.title: Arkansas Twister at Magic Springs

videoEditingDetails.description: POV footage of riding Arkansas Twister

activities.description: Host discusses Le Monstre at La Ronde

narrativeProgression.description: Discusses Le Monstre at La Ronde, highlighting its massive potential but acknowledging the logistical hurdles preventing an RMC conversion.
Host expresses hope for the ride's continued operation, regardless of whether it remains a wooden coaster

scenes.thematicElements: Ride scale, international projects, limitations of RMC operations, preservation of classic coasters.
scenes.title: Le Monstre at La Ronde

videoEditingDetails.description: Footage of Le Monstre roller coaster

narrativeProgression.description: Discusses Hurler at Carowinds, highlighting its mediocre status and the potential for a significant improvement with an RMC conversion.
Host notes the positive impact of Twisted Timbers (a converted Hurler clone) and suggests Hurler may be the most likely candidate

scenes.thematicElements: Ride comparisons, potential for standout attractions, park investment, recent coaster additions.
scenes.title: Hurler at Carowinds

activities.description: Host summarizes the video and invites viewers to share their thoughts
Host encourages viewers to follow him on social media

narrativeProgression.description: Summarizes the discussion and concludes the video.

videoEditingDetails.description: Logos for Facebook and Instagram with usernames appear on screen, fading in and out

climax.description: The climax is not clearly defined as the video doesn't follow a traditional narrative structure. Instead, it presents a series of potential candidates with varying degrees of likelihood for conversion.

storylines.description: This video discusses potential candidates for the Rocky Mountain Construction (RMC) I-Box conversion treatment, focusing on wooden roller coasters in North America. The host provides insights into why each ride could be a good candidate and the potential impact of the conversion.

content_metadata.title: More Wooden Coasters I Want to See RMC'd

trimmingSuggestions.description: The intro montage could be shortened slightly, focusing on a few key visually impactful shots to grab attention without feeling too long.
The outro could be condensed, fading in the social media information more quickly rather than having individual fades for each element.

timecoded_text_to_speech.text: Welcome to a new video everyone.
I am back with another video where I will be discussing my thoughts on what wooden
coasters in North America could potentially receive the Rocky Mountain Construction
Ibox conversion.
I already did one of these videos several months back, which I will put in a card above
the video, but I had several comments on that original video about some other potential
contenders as well as some more I had in mind, and I couldn't fit everyone into a single
video.
Although I think these rides could all make for great conversions, realistically I do
not think many of these, if any at all, will receive the treatment at least in the coming
few years.
I am just discussing a few more potential candidates since more were suggested by you,
and it's always interesting to think about the prospect of more exciting conversions
from the geniuses at Rocky Mountain Construction.
Just as with the first video, I also want to preface this by saying I am a huge fan of
wooden coasters, and it is unfortunate that the already low number of wooden coasters
in the world is continually dropping, but at the same time, new ones are still being built
albeit at a slower rate compared to steel.
Also all of the current wooden coasters that have been RMC are rides that were known
for being absolutely awful, boring, and unpopular coasters.
If wooden coasters can be saved by being refurbished and remaining as wooden tracks coasters,
I also see that as a great option.
Also note that these coasters are no particular order.
Starting off the list, we have Chita at Wild Adventures in Valdesta, Georgia.
This most likely won't happen, but it would be a cheaper alternative to a brand new ground-up
coaster, and Hershian never invests much into this park.
This custom coaster's international creation opened in 2001 and has a Gerst Lauer trains.
I've heard many complaints about this giving an unbearable ride and the out and back layout
would make for a unique RMC.
I could see maybe something similar to on Tame that will be Holland, but scaled back.
Being a fan of older CCIs though, and seeing how more are beginning to disappear, I would
actually just love to see this given a complete refurbishment by GCI if nothing else.
Next is Twister 2 at Elich Gardens.
Another park which never gets any kind of real significant investment.
I know the future of this park seems very uncertain with the city project which came
delight last year, but frankly, I don't know if that will ever happen.
In any case, this ride is not looked at as being very good by many, and doesn't seem
to even hold a candle to the original Mr. Twister, which this ride is based on, which
is really a shame.
I think this could make for a cool, twisted, compact RMC, and would easily be the start
attraction here.
Elich Gardens is sorely lacking that one true standout coaster from their park.
The closest thing they have is a Vekoma SLC.
Mount Olympus and Wisconsin Dells has two woodies which do look quite good, but they could
both make for a good RMC for the small park.
These are Zeus and Zyclops.
Two out of the three CCIs this park is home to, and all three opened and backed back years
in the 1990s.
I personally would pick Zeus out of these if I had to pick one to receive the treatment
as it has a simple out and back layout, while Cyclops looks like an awesome Twister and
has that at least once infamous drop with Insane ejector air.
This is another case of most likely not happening, but Mount Olympus is a small park and credit
where it is due.
They do try to invest as much as they can and have a few pretty solid looking coasters
in addition to a couple others over the years that have been removed, so I wouldn't
necessarily put it past the owners either to invest some money into converting one of their
four wooden coasters into a hybrid.
Arkansas Twister at Magic Springs is a wooden out and back coaster that opened at the
park in 1992, but was relocated from Boardwalk and Baseball in Florida, where it opened in
1978 as Florida Hurricane.
Magic Springs is a park that actually added quite a few coasters for a small park in the
early 2000s, adding a new coaster every two years starting in 2000 and ending after
And they were pretty generous investments for this park.
Sadly, they haven't received any new coaster since 2006 though.
They could definitely use a modern thrill coaster to get more people to travel out to this
park, and I think an RMC conversion of Arkansas Twister could help with that.
I don't think this is very likely, because it is a pretty small park with a limited budget,
and Arkansas Twister is somewhat of a classic ride, despite many people not seeming to enjoy
it that much.
I actually do think an RMC Raptor clone would be more likely and perhaps even more well
suited for this park, but of course having RMC convert this wooden coaster would be a
very good way to help keep costs down while adding an amazing top tier coaster to this
park.
Maybe instead of converting Arkansas Twister, they could have GCI retract and Reprofile
the ride, or even use some of that new GCI hybrid track that was unveiled, and it might
even be cheaper than an RMC conversion.
RMC could even keep this a wooden coaster by retracting it with their topraterque as
well as another alternative option.
Next up is a coaster that so many people want to see RMC, and for good reason, as it
has literally massive potential.
This would be Monster at LaRonde.
Now this is probably never going to happen.
Ever.
First of all, RMC doesn't have any offices in Canada, which prevents them from building
in Canada, and they like to build all of their rides themselves.
But also, let's be real.
This is LaRonde we're talking about.
I did want to discuss it as an option though, because so many people would like to see
this.
This monstrous wooden coaster would certainly make for a great candidate with its sprawling,
tooling twisted layout, and so much could be done here.
It seems this old ride rarely ever doles any more based on what I've heard from many
enthusiasts, and also seems to not be well maintained.
This is one of the very few large-scale wooden coasters left that could receive the RMC
treatment as well.
I do hope Monster is around for a very long time to come though, whether that be as a wooden
coaster or as a conversion.
This is a massive ride in LaRonde really can't afford to keep losing attractions.
Lastly, we have Hurler at Carolins.
This is one of the Hurler clones that opened in the 90s under Paramount, and of course,
Hurler at King's Dominion was transformed into the amazing Ejector Air Machine, twisted
timbers for 2018.
Many people have been clamoring for an RMC redo of the Carolins Hurler ever since finding
out about twisted timbers.
Whether that would be a clone of twisted timbers or just a similar RMC conversion.
Either way, I don't think you could go wrong with this.
Giving Hurler the treatment would certainly improve Carolins' coaster lineup that much
more, giving them much needed depth beyond the top 4 or 5 in the park.
I feel inclined to say, I feel that this coaster may be the most likely out of all these
to be converted, though I have heard from a couple sources that this may not be an option
for Carolins at this time.
However, nothing reliable has ever come to fruition regarding this, so RMC Hurler could
still potentially be in the cards, though it surely wouldn't happen for at least
another few years.
One thing that could go against this is that there had been some new trackwork done to
Hurler when I was there in 2019 and a trim break right after the drop and before the first
turn, which I believe may have been added very recently as well.
This doesn't really give much credence to this not potentially happening, though.
I do hope that Carolins receives a good modern woody, like something from GCI, and I do
think that will happen eventually.
They will definitely need a good thrilling wooden coaster if Hurler is converted.
When it comes to Hurler itself, to me it was just a mediocre ride.
It's pretty smooth and comfortable, but it didn't really do much for me, even though
it is still the park's best coaster besides the top four in my opinion.
Thank you all for watching this video.
Let me know in the comments what your thoughts are about any of these wooden coasters receiving
the RMC Iron Horse Conversion in the coming years.
I would love to hear your thoughts.
Be sure to like my page CoasterDaddy and Facebook, and follow me at CoasterDaddy official
on Instagram, as well as subscribing and liking this video if you enjoyed it.
This is CoasterDaddy.
Bye.

youtube_description:
In this video, I will be looking at more coasters in North America that could potentially receive the RMC Iron Horse conversion. Check out my original video for other coasters! Link below.

Other Possible RMC Conversions: 
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bFoCaFXGWC0 

Like, comment and subscribe for more rollercoaster and amusement park content every week!

Merchandise: https://teespring.com/stores/coaster-daddy?page=1

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Coaster-Daddy-1281712168647767/

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/coasterdaddyofficial/ 

Intro: "Prepare to Fight" by AMRPHIS
https://www.youtube.com/user/AMRPHIS
#rmc #carowinds #besthybridcoasters
youtube_title: More RMC Conversions for North America (May 2020)
